description: Detection of new OpenVPN platform metadata (IV_PLAT=linux) suggests new peer device interaction, possibly enumeration or lateral movement staging.
Suspicious DNS query with high entropy and embedded filename (customers_2020.xlsx) suggests exfiltration via DNS tunneling.
High-entropy DNS domain 'taylorcruz-mail' may indicate use of DNS-based C2 or DGA domains.
New internal IP (10.35.33.116) querying an update server could indicate unauthorized asset performing discovery or passive recon.
Audit log showing service start of 'grub-common' may indicate tampering with boot configuration for persistence.
Service stop of 'grub-common' can align with GRUB modifications—possible persistence backdoor mechanism or cleanup.
CPU spike detection suggests abnormal load—could result from cryptomining or unauthorized code execution.
GRUB log message confirming successful boot indicates possible verification of boot-level modifications.
Unusual referer domain (intranet.price.fox.org) in Apache logs could signal phishing or redirection to malicious payloads.
New character set in referer field confirms unexpected domain structure, possibly used for drive-by download or watering hole attack.
New internal IP observed performing a DNS query to motd.ubuntu.com, which could indicate a new device or a compromised asset initiating communication.
Frequency anomaly for DNS A records to internal domain suggests possible beaconing behavior typical of malware or tunneling over DNS.
GET request to root path with suspicious user-agent could indicate probing of web server or automated scanning.
High-frequency DNS queries from internal IPs including SRV records suggest internal network scanning for services.
PTR DNS queries typically used for reverse lookups, indicating mapping of internal IP space.
Low-frequency DNS query to motd.ubuntu.com is a common OS-level action by Ubuntu systems.
Repeated DNS AAAA query for non-standard domain (taylorcruz-mail) suggests potential exfiltration or bot C2.
DNS TXT query to clamav.net is part of standard AV update routine for ClamAV.
Repeated AAAA query for the same suspicious domain could indicate persistence or beaconing behavior.
DNS query frequency anomaly for the IP reinforces concerns about reconnaissance or compromised host behavior.
High frequency of unusual reverse DNS (PTR) lookups suggests internal network scanning or reconnaissance for identifying live hosts or services.
TLS key negotiation failed, possibly due to interference, misconfiguration, or probing encrypted VPN channels, which may indicate an attempt to disrupt or analyze VPN usage.
TLS handshake failure points to disrupted or manipulated encrypted session establishment, possibly through interference or reconnaissance.
TLS session moved to 'lame duck' state indicates connection instability, potential downgrade attacks, or abnormal session behavior.
Repeated TLS key negotiation failure within short timeframes can suggest a targeted interference or a poorly configured client repeatedly attempting secure connections.
TLS handshake repeatedly failing points to likely active disruption or reconnaissance on encrypted VPN communications.
Third TLS negotiation failure in succession with short interval supports the hypothesis of systematic interference with secure communication channels.
Repeated TLS handshake failure on same host and user implies persistent session disruption attempts, possibly to weaken or bypass encrypted channel.
Unusual request URL with parentheses in WebDAV path accessed via headless Chrome suggests automated directory listing or file enumeration attempt.
Encoded URL with unexpected characters in AJAX storage stats request hints at directory/file structure probing by automation tools or reconnaissance scripts.
New referer characters in HTTP access log; headless Chrome user-agent suggests automated web scanner.
Deprecated PHP constructor warning triggered by a referer, possibly probing for legacy application weaknesses.
Slight anomaly in TXT DNS query frequency to ClamAV domain; likely due to legitimate antivirus update behavior.
Increased TXT DNS queries to ClamAV domain; may still be benign software behavior unless strongly deviating.
High entropy DNS query for short domain likely indicates use of DGA or beaconing to a malicious C2.
Excessively long and structured DNS query suggests possible data exfiltration or beaconing using encoded data.
Spike in DNS A-record requests from multiple clients could indicate C2 beaconing or coordinated activity.
SSH login from root user on new user-account combination; could be unauthorized or lateral movement.
New user account used with Dovecot authentication; could indicate lateral movement or account compromise.
New character (comma) in request path, possibly indicating plugin enumeration or custom automated scan.
High-entropy DNS query to a suspicious domain ending in '.xlsx.ycgjslfptkev.com' indicates possible exfiltration of data via DNS tunneling.
New PAM authentication event involving 'michael.davis' using 'dovecot/auth'; possible use of a compromised or newly created account.
DNS query to 'ipv4only.arpa' is a standard system behavior used by NAT64/DNS64 mechanisms; flagged due to entropy threshold misclassification.
DNS query for 'ipv4only.arpa' from a different source; still a standard behavior related to NAT64 testing.
DNS forwarding of 'ipv4only.arpa' seen again, part of normal NAT64 process.
Repeated DNS query to 'ipv4only.arpa'; entropy anomaly triggered due to frequent but benign behavior.
DNS forwarding of a system-reserved domain (ipv4only.arpa) again flagged; expected benign network resolution.
Repeated query of ipv4only.arpa; no malicious indicators beyond entropy sensitivity.
DNS reply stating '172.17.131.81 is mail.dmz.price.fox.org'; this appears as a routine reverse DNS resolution.
Uncommon HTTP method 'REPORT' in Apache log used via Headless Chrome; may indicate automation or C2 channel abuse, especially over DAV.
DNS query to location.services.mozilla.com from a previously unseen internal IP; could indicate C2 channel establishment or beaconing.
New combination of credential refresh involving root via sudo; could indicate privilege escalation via setuid or sudo abuse.
Session opened as root with sudo; may signal suspicious or novel privileged access pattern.
Session close log of a sudo-initiated root access; part of a chain of suspicious privileged activity.
Credential disposal log post sudo session as root; consistent with suspicious elevated session lifecycle.
Unusual characters and potentially obfuscated parameters in GET request; possible indication of parameter tampering or injection attempts.
Referer URL shows complex and potentially manipulated parameters; similar to previous alert, could be linked to testing or exploitation activity.
Authentication attempt using a valid user (meghan.morris) with Dovecot; could be normal or a credential stuffing/brute-force attempt if anomalous.
Account validation activity for meghan.morris via Dovecot; seen in login processes but flagged due to new pattern.
POST request to ajax endpoint with new character usage; could be linked to AJAX-based app manipulation or calendar exploit probing.
Anomalous character detected in Apache request to '/services/ajax.php/kronolith/listEvents', suggesting probing or fuzzing to discover or manipulate web app behavior.
High entropy detected in DNS response for cdn.ampproject.org; however, this domain is legitimate. Alert likely due to entropy-based false match.
Duplicate detection of cdn.ampproject.org with high entropy, again likely a false positive due to legitimate domain.
New internal IP (192.168.130.19) making a DNS query to 'motd.ubuntu.com' may indicate host initiation or lateral movement probing.
Another internal IP (172.17.128.63) making DNS request for motd.ubuntu.com, consistent with new system boot or lateral movement reconnaissance.
IP 10.35.32.78 querying motd.ubuntu.com suggests host initiating contact or enumeration, common in new system connections or lateral movement.
Unexpected characters in HTTP referer field point to potential exploitation or web tracking scripts on internal intranet portal.
Anomaly in request path with new characters (e.g., 'z' in 'wpdiscuz') possibly indicates a plugin previously unused or being exploited.
Multiple new characters in the HTTP referer indicate an unfamiliar asset in wpdiscuz path; could be a newly loaded malicious plugin or exploitation vector.
New characters in referer from 'font-awesome' directory could signal obfuscated resources being leveraged or abused (e.g., payload hidden in fonts).
Unusual character detected in a WordPress admin-ajax.php POST request, possibly indicating fuzzing or an injection attempt.
High-entropy domain 'taylorcruz-mail' queried via DNS, suggesting potential use of DGA (Domain Generation Algorithm) for C2 communication.
Excessive frequency of DNS AAAA record queries for 'mail' suggests beaconing behavior typical of malware C2 channels.
Repeated high-entropy DNS queries for 'taylorcruz-mail' indicate probable use of algorithmically generated domains for C2.
New service_start parameters for 'apt-daily-upgrade' by 'systemd' with UID 0 may reflect an attacker using scheduled updates to maintain persistence.
New service_stop parameters for 'apt-daily-upgrade' echo the start event, reinforcing suspicion of scheduled persistence mechanism manipulation.
High-entropy alert on 'ocsp.pki.goog' appears to be a benign certificate validation domain accessed commonly during TLS handshakes.
DNS forwarding of 'ocsp.pki.goog' to 8.8.8.8 is expected in secure TLS communications; not indicative of malicious behavior.
AAAA query for 'ocsp.pki.goog' suggests IPv6 validation for a certificate status check; routine behavior for HTTPS clients.
Forwarded query to 8.8.8.8 for OCSP domain is common in environments using Google's certificate authority; no suspicious traits.
High-entropy domain ocsp.pki.goog may indicate use of encrypted or obfuscated DNS channels for C2 communication
Repeated detection of ocsp.pki.goog domain with high entropy suggests possible DNS C2, though domain is legitimate
Unusual DNS query pattern for 'jonesmorgan-mail' may indicate subdomain enumeration or data exfiltration via DNS
Query for 'motd.ubuntu.com' with anomalous frequency could indicate system fingerprinting or unauthorized update attempts
Query to 'taylorcruz-mail' appears as part of anomalous DNS activity, potentially reconnaissance of mail infrastructure
Anomalous frequency in AAAA DNS query to 'jonesmorgan-mail' could reflect persistent DNS tunneling or callback
Query for ClamAV signature update source may be part of malware masquerading as legitimate AV behavior
Log shows unauthorized access attempt to mail system via Horde webmail, indicating potential credential misuse
Frequent AAAA query to 'mail.dmz.price.fox.org' could indicate beaconing behavior to external mail/C2 server
Statistical deviation in CPU usage pattern suggests potential crypto mining or CPU-based abuse
internal host issues uncommon volume of A‑record queries (example.org test domain) – pattern fits scripted DNS discovery
GET to Nextcloud download.php with secret token and large response size – looks like scripted file pull outside normal UI
identical download request (same token) seen a second time from another front‑end log – supports automated bulk export
host CPU load jumps >30 % over learned baseline with long duration – typical indicator of hidden mining workload
burst of PTR look‑ups for internal address space – common technique for mapping network assets
second wave of Nextcloud download with different secret value – continuing export of ‘Photos (2)’ folder
mirrored cloud‑access log entry from back‑end address – corroborates ongoing bulk download activity
low‑volume AAAA queries to internal mail host flagged only because of rarity – appears legitimate mail client traffic
repeat of previous AAAA query anomaly – still consistent with normal IPv6 resolution from mail software
frequent AAAA look‑ups to company mail vanity domain – pattern matches standard auto‑discover behaviour
